div.p: Ḥaḍramawt is a region in the far south of the Arabian Peninsula. In addition to the coastal plain, on which al-Mukalla and aš-šiḥr are the largest cities, the region includes a desert-like plateau in the hinterland cut through by a fertile contiguous valley system – the Wādī Ḥaḍramawt proper with its side valleys. Since the early 19th century, large-scale migration has established sizable Ḥaḍramī minorities around the Indian Ocean from Southeast Asia to East Africa.
Historically, Ḥaḍramawt was famous for its production of frankincense.
Research on Ḥaḍramī Arabic began at the beginning of the 20th century. The first studies focused on texts; but recent ones include descriptions of the grammatical features of Ḥaḍramī Arabic.

Landberg (1901) is a collection of texts in the Ḥaḍramī dialect. Its first section consists of two goodbye ditties and ten qaṣīdas with linguistic commentary. The following prose section contains texts on 12 different professions in the Ḥaḍramawt. The final section is an extensive glossary. Hein & Müller (1909) is another large collection of texts collected during the Austrian expedition in 1902. It includes 43 narratives, 40 poems, 16 riddles, nine adages, and three games.

After a long break in the research on the Ḥaḍramī dialect, Abdullah Hassan Al-Saqqaf published several studies on it: Al-Saqqaf (1999) is a full description of the dialect of the Ḥaḍramawt; Al-Saqqaf (2005) treats the verbal morphology; Al-Saqqaf (2006a) is on co-referential devices and offers a good overview of previous studies on this dialect; and Al-Saqqaf (2006b) analyzes loanwords in Ḥaḍramī Arabic.
Al-Saqqaf’s “Wādī Ḥaḍramawt Arabic” in EALL IV, 687-699 is a concise grammatical sketch of the dialect.
